indicators.justification:
Information on greenhouse gases are available. However, there are two great difficulties. The first problem is that the data is out of date. On the website it indicates that there is data available until 2020, but when it is downloaded, there is only data available until 2018. The second problem is that the data can only be downloaded in bulk in a ZIP folder and inside it contains the files in xls formats or cvs, but you can't see the data online, there is only the download option.

Sources

#1 Chilean National Greenhouse Gas Inventory System: https://snichile.mma.gob.cl/documentos/

evidence.title: Chilean National Greenhouse Gas Inventory System

indicators.justification:
Information on endangered species and ecosystems is available online, but not in open data format. Information only exists through reports (PDF) under the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity. This report has been carried out in Chile since 2003. In 2020 the sixth report was published. The information in the report is very useful and covers all biodiversity in Chile. But, the information is not in open data format.

Sources
#1 Sixth National Biodiversity Report of Chile: https://mma.gob.cl/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/6NR_FINAL_ALTA-web.pdf

2#  IPT: http://gbif-chile.mma.gob.cl/ipt

evidence.title: Sixth National Biodiversity Report of Chile

indicators.justification:
Information on climate vulnerability is available as open data in the Climate Risk Atlas for Chile. This is a recent project of the Ministry of the Environment of the Government of Chile, developed by the Climate and Resilience Research Center (CR2) and the Center for Global Change (CCG-Universidad Católica de Chile). There is also an API.

Sources

#1 Climate Risk Atlas:  https://arclim.mma.gob.cl

indicators.justification:
Chile at this time does not yet have a law for the final owners of the companies. The latest advance on this issue was a public consultation carried out in 2020 by ChileCompra and the Financial Analysis Unit (UAF). The private website https://sec.equifax.cl offers commercial information about delinquent and protested debts, real estate, vehicles, identification number of the owners, date of birth, date of death, address, marital status, among others. . But, to access this information you must pay. The veracity of the information provided cannot be verified.

Sources

#1 Public consultation on the proposal to create a registry of final beneficiary of legal persons: https://www.chilecompra.cl/2020/09/consulta-publica-sobre-propuesta-de-creacion-de-un-registro-de-beneficiario-final-de-las-personas-juridicas/

#2 Private Information Service: https://sec.equifax.cl/

indicators.justification:
Information on civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) if available as open data. However, the portal does not have the information well stored and distributed. In the "Datos Abiertos" section, not all data is available. You have to click on other sections or enter certain views to access the complete information.

Sources
#1 HEALTH INFORMATION STATISTICS DEPARTMENT: https://deis.minsal.cl/#datosabiertos

indicators.justification:
I believe that there is partial information on the real-time capacity of the healthcare system available as open data. The context of COVID-19 revealed certain information such as the availability of ICU beds and the financing of the hospital execution by FONASA. However, the information is not centralized and requires a more complex search.

Sources
#1 Access to Public Information of the Ministry of Health: http://transparencia.redsalud.gov.cl/transparencia/
#2 HEALTH INFORMATION STATISTICS DEPARTMENT: https://deis.minsal.cl/#datosabiertos
#3 ICOVID Chile: https://www.icovidchile.cl/capacidad-hospitalaria
#4 FONASA: https://www.fonasa.cl/sites/fonasa/datos-abiertos

indicators.justification:
The Open Budget Portal publishes and displays transactional data on the execution of fiscal spending by the Presidency of the Republic, the National Congress, the Judiciary, the Comptroller General of the Republic, the Public Ministry and each of the Ministries and their respective services, in a simple and interactive way. Its objective is to allow citizens, public institutions, civil society and all those interested in the management of public resources to easily know where and how public sector resources are spent.

Sources
#1 Open Budget Portal Chile: https://presupuestoabierto.gob.cl

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

indicators.justification:
In accordance with Law No. 20,880 on Probity in the Public Function and Prevention of Conflicts of Interest, the Office of the Comptroller General of the Republic and the Council for Transparency make declarations of interests and assets available to citizens, in specific cases that the law indicates. This does not include all public officials.

Sources

#1 Infoprobidad: https://www.infoprobidad.cl/#!/inicio
# Declaración Jurada: https://www.declaracionjurada.cl/dip/index.html

indicators.justification:
The data.gob.cl portal, being a centralized repository of data from public institutions, serves to make available to different actors data generated with public budget and in open formats, for free consumption by the interested parties. This data can be consumed by downloading from the platform or consuming directly from the API that generates data.gob.cl. Allowing the generation of value such as visualizations, applications, studies, research and services, among others.

Sources

#1 Chile Open Data Portal: https://datos.gob.cl
#2 Information on the budget assigned to the Digital Government division, in charge of managing the open data portal. See page 922: http://www.dipres.gob.cl/597/articles-229524_doc_pdf.pdf

indicators.justification:
There is very little evidence of local governments managing open data effectively. In Chile's open data portal, there is data for some municipalities and local governments, but it is not representative of all municipalities in the country and it is not up-to-date. The most recent example and identified good practice is in the Municipality of Puente Alto. But, there is no more recent evidence.

Sources

#1 Puente Alto Open Data Portal: https://datos.mpuentealto.cl/home
#2 Chile Open Data Portal: https://datos.gob.cl/group/comunidad

responses.response_text: The examples given are exceptions: the majority of cities and regions do not have the capacity to effectively manage data.

indicators.justification:
There is no evidence of data interoperability. However, if there is a law that provides support for interoperability. LAW 21180. DIGITAL TRANSFORMATION OF THE STATE. Article 19: Mandatory use of electronic platforms. The bodies of the Administration will be obliged to provide and use electronic platforms appropriately for the purposes of keeping electronic files, which must comply with security, interoperability, interconnection and cybersecurity standards.

indicators.justification:
Within the framework of Commitment No. 11 of Chile's 2018-2020 Open Government Action Plan, the creation of a registry of final beneficiary of legal persons was proposed. It is currently under discussion between the executive and the parliament. Currently, there is no registry or open mechanism to know who are the final owners of the companies in Chile.

Sources
#1 Result of Public Consultation for Proposal of Registration of Final Owners of the Companies: http://uaf.ogp.gob.cl/assets/pdf/Informe-Cartilla-Resultados-consulta-publica.pdf

indicators.justification:
Chile does not yet have a comprehensive framework for consistent data management and publication. Not because there is no knowledge, but because there is no cross-talk for data management. The Technical Standard for Open Data Publication in Chile is sufficient to standardize a consistent data publication. A framework with the force of law is required.

Sources

#1 Technical Standard for the Publication of Open Data in Chile: https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/datos.gob.cl/NormaTecnicaPublicacionDatosChile_v2-1.pdf

There is a comprehensive framework for data exchange within public institutions in Chile. However, there is no framework to allow and promote this exchange from the private sector. Nor is there verifiable information on the effectiveness of these laws in practice.

indicators.justification:
In Chile there is a legal framework that allows protection of personal data (Law 19628. ABOUT PROTECTION OF PRIVATE LIFE. MINISTRY GENERAL SECRETARIAT OF THE PRESIDENCY). However, this law is out of date for the current context. In this law, there are no references on algorithmic transparency and no clear responsibilities are established for the use of personal data by the private sector.

Sources

#1:Law 19628. ABOUT PROTECTION OF PRIVATE LIFE. MINISTRY GENERAL SECRETARIAT OF THE PRESIDENCY https://www.bcn.cl/leychile/navegar?idNorma=141599

#2 Law 21096 CONSECRATES THE RIGHT TO PROTECTION OF PERSONAL DATA http://bcn.cl/2f9w0

indicators.justification:
Chile does not have a legal framework with the force of law for the publication of open data. The Technical Standard for the Publication of Open Data in Chile is the only existing framework in this matter. However, its application is voluntary. There are particular advances of certain ministries, but there is no comprehensive and national policy.

The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
There is a legal framework that allows access to public information. However, it does not mention that publica agencies are required to publish data about its performance.

Sources
#1 LAW 20285 ABOUT ACCESS TO PUBLIC INFORMATION: http://bcn.cl/2f8ep
#2 DECREE 13. REGULATION OF LAW No. 20,285 ABOUT ACCESS TO PUBLIC INFORMATION: http://bcn.cl/2j53u

evidence.title: LAW 20285 ABOUT ACCESS TO PUBLIC INFORMATION
DECREE 13. REGULATION OF LAW No. 20,285 ABOUT ACCESS TO PUBLIC INFORMATION

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding the number of requests submitted and processed.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding material withheld and the reasons for withholding it.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding appeals to RTI determinations and their results.
The framework requires that information is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification: As the data of the companies is not completely open and the data of the final owners is not regulated, it is unknown if there are services or products that are using this type of information. However, it is not ruled out that there are private initiatives, but that they are not public.

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of such products or services in the country.

indicators.justification: Given the unavailability of comprehensive information on land tenure, there is no public evidence that land data is being used to influence policies for equitable and inclusive land tenure and use.

indicators.justification:
In Chile there are cases of actors who use data for accountability purposes or to inform citizens. Although, the use is not massive. Yes, positive cases can be identified by the Academy, Civil Society and the Private Sector.

Sources

#1 https://observatoriofiscal.cl
#2 https://www.chiletransparente.cl
#3 https://www.ciperchile.cl/transparencia/
#4 https://cchc.cl/centro-de-informacion/indicadores/
#5 https://www.icovidchile.cl

responses.response_text: There are a number of cases of actors or entities using this kind of open data for accountability purposes.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used for accountability purposes?
Civil society organizations regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The media regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
Scholars or academic institutions regularly use this data for accountability purposes.
The private sector regularly uses this data for accountability purposes.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
There is evidence that public procurement data is being analyzed to improve procurement practices and for citizen oversight. However, there is no evidence of the use of the data by the private sector.

Sources 
#1 Ministry of Finance sends draft Law on Public Procurement to generate more transparency and competition in the transactions carried out by the State: https://www.chilecompra.cl/2021/03/hacienda-envia-proyecto-de-ley-de-compras-publicas-para-generar-mas-transparencia-y-competencia-en-las-transacciones-que-realiza-el-estado/

#2 Civil Society: Observatorio del Gasto Fiscal - Red Flags: https://redflags.observatoriofiscal.cl

There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
